questions.question: A 52-year-old male presents with worsening shortness of breath and fatigue. An echocardiogram shows left ventricular dilation and significant aortic regurgitation. Which of the following are the possible conditions causing Aortic regurgitation? Ankylosing Spondylitis Aortic Dissection Marfan's Syndrome Syphilis
questions.explanation: Regurgitation Aetiology Conditions affecting the valve structure and its functions Conditions causing valve root dilatation Bicuspid Aortic valve (Congenital) Infective Endocarditis Rheumatic fever Myxomatous prolapse of the valve Scarring of the valve by Syphilis (statement 4) Ankylosing spondylitis (statement 1) Radiation Trauma Aortic Dissection (statement 2) Aortitis (Takayasu arteritis or GCA) Hypertension Marfan syndrome (statement 3) Medial Degeneration Nonsyndromic familial aneurysm Pathophysiology Clinical symptoms Usually, it starts appearing only after 10 to 15 years. Symptoms specific to AR : Palpitations (more in the supine position) Head pounding sensation Other symptoms: Paroxysmal Nocturnal dyspnea (sometimes the early one to appear) Angina on rest or exertion & breathlessness on exertion Orthopnea and diaphoresis Peripheral edema Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 1987, 1988

questions.question: Match the following murmurs with the respective conditions. S.No Murmur Condition 1) a) Mitral Stenosis 2) b) Aortic Stenosis 3) c) Mitral Regurgitation 4) d) Aortic Regurgitation

A 25 y/o patient with h/o pulmonary hypertension presents with exertional dyspnea. You auscultate a high-pitched, decrescendo diastolic murmur at the second left intercostal space, radiating along the left sternal border that increases with inspiration. Which of the following murmurs is this?
questions.explanation: diastolic murmur heard at the second left intercostal space, radiating along the left sternal border that becomes louder with inspiration indicates a Graham steel murmur. Graham Steel Murmur: A high-pitched, decrescendo diastolic murmur is best heard at the second left intercostal space and radiates along the left sternal border. Often associated with pulmonary regurgitation (PR) , particularly in patients with significant pulmonary artery (PA) hypertension . It can become louder with inspiration. Accompanied by a loud and sometimes palpable P2 and right ventricular (RV) lift. pulmonary regurgitation" data-author="" data-hash="8873" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" height="494" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/0tgpYHQephSIFpUKaWP41744312057.png" width="494" /> Austin Flint Murmur (Option B) : Soft, low-pitched, rumbling mid-to-late diastolic murmur produced by the diastolic displacement of the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve due to the aortic regurgitation. Not indicative of hemodynamically significant mitral valve obstruction. Carey-Coombs Murmur (Option C) : Mid-diastolic murmur is commonly heard in cases of acute rheumatic fever , likely due to flow through an edematous mitral valve Disappears with resolution of the acute episode. Gibson murmur (Option D): It is a continuous, rumbling heart murmur that's usually heard in the second left interspace near the sternum & often seen in patent ductus arteriosus (PDA)

questions.question: A 65-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of left arm pain and intermittent dizziness. O/E, you find a notable difference in blood pressure readings: 150/90 mmHg in the right arm and 100/60 mmHg in the left arm. Which condition is least likely to cause this variation?
questions.explanation: differences in blood pressure between the arms, as both arms receive blood from the same arch branches. Therefore, supravalvular aortic stenosis is least likely to cause this variation. Coarctation of the Aorta (CoA) (Option A) typically causes lower blood pressure in the lower extremities compared to the upper extremities, but can also lead to differences between arms due to collateral circulation. Aortic Dissection (Option B) can cause differences in blood pressure between arms if the dissection extends into the subclavian arteries or affects the branches that supply the arms. Takayasu Arteritis (Option D) is an inflammatory condition that often affects the aorta and its branches and may cause stenosis or occlusion leading to differences in blood pressure between the arms. Reference: Davidson’s Principles and Practice of Medicine, 24th Edition, Page 534 pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3327834/ pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/33692296/

Mitral regurgitation b. Mid-diastolic rumble with opening snap 3. Mitral stenosis c. Harsh systolic murmur radiating to the carotids 4. Tricuspid regurgitation d. Holosystolic murmur radiating to the axilla

Loud S1 Malar rash Distended neck veins Tricuspid stenosis Rheumatic (coexist with mitral stenosis) Tall P waves in the lead II Right axis deviation Large ‘a’ wave Blunted ‘y’ wave Mid-diastolic murmur Carvallo’s sign Tricuspid regurgitation Rheumatic ‘ C-v’ wave Steep ‘y’ descent Blowing holosystolic murmur Systolic liver pulsation Carvallo’s sign Aortic regurgitation Infective endocarditis Bicuspid aortic valve Left axis deviation LV hypertrophy Changes are seen only in advanced cases Decrescendo diastolic murmur Wide pulse pressure Water hammer pulse Aortic stenosis Degenerative calcification 53% of cases have congenital bicuspid aortic valve Accentuated “a” wave due to reduced RV cavity distensibility from the hypertrophied interventricular septum Crescendo-decrescendo ejection murmur . Gallavardin effect Pulmonary regurgitation Pulmonary hypertension Right axis deviation RV hypertrophy. Large ‘a’ wave End–diastolic murmur (Graham Steel murmur) Cardiac MRI is the IOC rather than echocardiography Pulmonary stenosis Congenital defect Systolic ejection murmur Wide split S2 Reference: Harrison’s Principle of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page 1978 - 2005

questions.question: A 6-year-old girl with a history of Tetralogy of Fallot repair 12 months ago presents with abdominal swelling and pedal oedema. Cardiac auscultation reveals an early diastolic murmur, and ECG shows right ventricular and atrial enlargement. Considering the suspicion of pulmonary regurgitation, which investigation is most appropriate for further evaluation?
questions.explanation: patients with repaired congenital heart defects , as it provides more anatomical details and helps precisely access the Right ventricular volume and function. PULMONARY REGURGITATION Aetiology Pulmonary artery hypertension - annular dilatation of the pulmonary valve Post-repair of Tetralogy of Fallot Post balloon valvotomy Marfan syndrome Pathophysiology Severe pulmonary regurgitation (PR) results in right ventricular enlargement and eccentric hypertrophy due to increased preload and afterload. A reverse pressure gradient from the pulmonary artery to the right ventricle drives the regurgitation, leading to a reduction in cardiac output over time. As the condition progresses, right atrial involvement may occur, elevating jugular venous pressure. Clinical features Fatigue, dyspnea, ascites, and pedal oedema Auscultation reveals an early diastolic murmur (Graham steel murmur) Investigations Chest X-ray: Enlarged right atrium and ventricular shadow Cardiac MRI: Investigation of choice, especially in patients with repaired congenital heart defects. Echocardiography (transthoracic): It helps assess pulmonary valve morphology and the direction of blood flow. (Option A and C) Cardiac catheterisation is not usually done but can be done during transcatheter pulmonary valve procedures. (Option D) Treatment Medical: Diuretics for symptoms of right-sided heart failure Surgical: Transcatheter pulmonic valve replacement. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 2005.

questions.question: A 10-year-old girl presents with exercise intolerance and occasional chest pain. Examination reveals a systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border and elevated jugular venous pressure. An echocardiogram shows a peak systolic gradient of 70 mmHg across the pulmonary valve, raising suspicion for pulmonary valve stenosis. Which of the following set of statements is true regarding this condition? Pulmonic stenosis is always congenital. Dysplastic valves leading to pulmonary stenosis are seen in Noonan syndrome. Severe PS is defined by peak systolic gradient across the PV>64 mmHg Percutaneous balloon valvuloplasty is indicated for all patients. Pulmonic stenosis usually leads to right ventricular hypertrophy.
questions.explanation: the peak systolic gradient exceeds 64 mmHg and typically leads to right ventricular hypertrophy due to pressure overload. PULMONARY STENOSIS Aetiology It is essentially a congenital disease, but it may be acquired (Statement 1 ruled out) Noonan syndrome (dysplastic pulmonary valve) (Statement 2) Tetralogy of Fallot Carcinoids Bulky vegetation or tumours Pathophysiology Pulmonary stenosis obstructs blood flow from the right ventricle, resulting in increased chamber pressure and subsequent right ventricular hypertrophy. (Statement 5) Right ventricular dysfunction occurs early and at lower pressures due to its reduced adaptability to hemodynamic burden compared to the left ventricle. Severity Defined by the systolic pressure gradient between the RV and PA Severe: Peak systolic gradient >64 mm hg (Statement 3) Moderate: Peak systolic gradient 36-64 mm hg Mild: Peak systolic gradient <36 hh mg Clinical features Mild to moderate PS are asymptomatic. Severe PS: Exertional dyspnea, fatigue, anginal pain and systemic venous congestion Syncope may occur during stress. Auscultation: Mid-systolic, crescendo-decrescendo murmur preceded by an ejection click. JVP: Prominent ‘a’ wave Investigations ECG: Right axis deviation + Right ventricular hypertrophy Chest X-ray: Post-stenotic dilation of the main PA and RV enlargement. Echocardiography: Transthoracic : Helps assess jet velocity, gradients, ventricular function Transesophageal (for detailed assessment of RV outflow tract) Management Medical: Diuretics for symptoms of right-sided heart failure Surgical: Percutaneous pulmonary balloon valvuloplasty (Statement 4 ruled out) is done when Symptomatic patients with moderate to severe PS Asymptomatic patients with peak gradient >64 mmHg or mean gradient > 35 mmHg. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 2004-2005.

questions.question: A 75-year-old male with a history of long-standing hypertension and atrial fibrillation presents with progressive fatigue & bilateral leg swelling. O/E, the patient has distended neck veins with the following waveform with a blowing holosystolic murmur that increases with inspiration. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: (prominent C-V waves, rapid Y descent) , ascites, and hepatomegaly. The characteristic finding is a blowing holosystolic murmur at the lower left sternal border, which increases with inspiration. TRICUSPID REGURGITATION Aetiology Primary (organic) Rheumatic disease Infective endocarditis Myxomatous - tricuspid valve prolapse Carcinoid Radiation Congenital (Ebstein’s anomaly) Trauma Myocardial infarction (Papillary muscle rupture) Secondary (functional) Long-standing pulmonary hypertension Left-sided heart disease Cardiomyopathy Atrial fibrillation - functional tricuspid regurgitation Chronic RV apical pacing (dyssynchrony) Pathophysiology An incompetent tricuspid valve allows blood to flow back from the right ventricle (RV) into the right atrium (RA) during systole, increasing RA and jugular venous pressures, seen as prominent C-V waves . Severe TR causes ventricularization of the RA waveform and RA dilation, resulting in reduced cardiac output that does not improve with exercise. Clinical features Features of right-sided heart failure Distended neck veins

questions.question: A 66-year-old female presents with fatigue, abdominal discomfort, and swelling in her legs. On examination, she has jugular venous distention with giant ‘a’ waves, hepatomegaly, and ascites. Auscultation reveals a diastolic murmur at the lower left sternal border, which increases in intensity with inspiration. What’s the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: jugular venous distention with giant ‘a’ waves , hepatomegaly , and ascites, is suggestive of Tricuspid stenosis. This condition is characterised by restricted blood flow from the right atrium to the right ventricle, often leading to right-sided heart failure symptoms like swelling in the legs, abdominal discomfort, and hepatomegaly. The presence of a diastolic murmur at the lower left sternal border further supports the diagnosis. TRICUSPID STENOSIS Aetiology Congenital Rheumatic origin (often coexists with mitral stenosis) Pathophysiology RA pressure ↑ , due to the diastolic pressure gradient between RA and RV, results in systemic venous congestion. Restricted forward flow of blood leads to ↓ cardiac output. Clinical features Fatigue Mild dyspnea Venous congestion (right-side heart failure): Hepatomegaly, ascites, oedema and may lead to cardiac cirrhosis. Physical examination: Jugular venous distension with prominent ‘a’ waves Auscultation: Mid-diastolic murmur at left lower sternal border Murmur increases with inspiration (Carvallo's sign). If mitral stenosis coexist Pulmonary artery hypertension Orthopnea due to pulmonary oedema Investigations Chest X-ray and ECG show features of RA enlargement Echocardiogram: Thickened tricuspid valve with diastolic doming and increased pressure gradient between RV and RA. Management Medical management: To reduce systemic venous congestion symptoms Dietary salt restriction Loop diuretics Surgical intervention: Valvular repair or Prosthetic valve replacement. Mitral stenosis (MS) (Option A) causes left atrial pressure overload , leading to pulmonary congestion and dyspnea, often with orthopnea and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea . This patient’s presentation is dominated by right-sided heart failure symptoms (ascites, hepatomegaly, oedema) without the significant pulmonary congestion typically seen in MS. Constrictive pericarditis (Option C) causes a thickened, non-compliant pericardium, limiting diastolic filling and leading to systemic venous congestion (jugular venous distension, hepatomegaly, ascites). Heart sounds may be muffled, and a pericardial knock can be present. Unlike tricuspid stenosis, constrictive pericarditis lacks a diastolic murmur. Aortic stenosis (Option D) causes left ventricular outflow obstruction, leading to exertional dyspnea, angina, and syncope, with a systolic ejection murmur radiating to the carotids. This patient's right-sided heart failure and diastolic murmur are more consistent with tricuspid stenosis, not aortic stenosis.

questions.question: A 69-year-old man presents with severe aortic regurgitation. He reports increasing fatigue, breathlessness, and episodes of dizziness. On auscultation, a diastolic murmur is heard along with a water-hammer pulse, and an echocardiogram shows significant left ventricular dilation and an ejection fraction of 55%. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.explanation: symptomatic, irrespective of their LV function. In asymptomatic progressive aortic regurgitation , AVR is advisable if LV dysfunction is evident. Regular non-invasive follow-up, once in 6-12 months, is necessary to monitor the development of myocardial dysfunction , as surgery delayed long after its development has minimal chances of completing LV recovery. Work up for Aortic regurgitation Investigations Findings ECG LV Hypertrophy Left axis deviation is noted QRS prolongation is seen occasionally LV Strain - ST wave depression and T wave inversion in I, aVL, V5, V6 leads Chest X-ray Inferolateral displacement of the apex is noted Aortic root dilation, often associated with aortic regurgitation, can be visible on a lateral chest X-ray as it fills the retrosternal space. It is not very sensitive to Aortic root conditions Echocardiogram Rapid fluttering of the anterior mitral valve during diastole because of the regurgitation. A dilated left ventricle is noted. It is the investigation of choice in Severe AR Cardiac Catheterization and Angiography (Occasionally done) To evaluate the LV function and regurgitation Done before surgery, but CT angiography can be done instead. Management Type Acute AR Chronic AR Medical (Option A) IV Diuretics (Furosemide) and Vasodilators (Sodium Nitroprusside) are used to stabilise the patient. Beta Blockers are contraindicated as they worsen the symptoms and reduce the cardiac output. Diuretics and Vasodilators like ACEi, CCB, Hydralazine, ARBs (can be used in chronic AR) to manage HTN; Target SBP <140 mm/Hg. For Angina: Nitrates For Syphilis: Benzathine Penicillin, 2.4 million units IM, three doses given with one week gap. Surgical Aortic valve replacement (AVR) is the treatment of choice, usually within 24 hours of diagnosis. Intra-Aortic Balloon pum p is contraindicated as it worsens the regurgitant flow. (Option C) AVR is indicated when developing LV dysfunction or symptoms . Transcatheter aortic valve implantation (Option B) is not suggeste d due to its limited success in chronic conditions. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 1988, 1989, 1990.

questions.question: Match the following signs with specific features Signs Features 1. Muller Sign a) Systolic pulsations of the Spleen 2. Rosenbach sign b) Visible systolic pulsation of the uvula 3. Gerhardt's sign c) Jarring motion of the head with each heartbeat 4. De-Musset sign d) Systolic pulsations of the Liver
questions.explanation: sign Systolic pulsations of the Liver Gerhardt's sign Systolic pulsations of the Spleen Quincke's sign Repeatedly alternating blushing and blanching of capillaries in the nail folds upon palpation (Capillary Pulsations) Landolphi sign Alternating systolic constriction and diastolic dilatation of pupils Traube Sign It is pistol shot sounds that are heard while auscultating over the femoral artery. Water-Hammer pulse Strong pulse that rises quickly and then drops off suddenly. Duroziez Sign It is a to-and-fro murmur heard while auscultating the femoral artery. De-Musset sign The jarring motion of the head with each heartbeat Examination Findings of Aortic Regurgitation Blood Pressure Elevated systolic pressure and decreased diastolic pressure result in increased arterial pulse pressure . Atrio-ventricular malformation and Atrio-ventricular I stula also show low diastolic BP due to continuous Korotko I sounds. Positive Hill’s sign is an abnormal difference in BP in the upper limb and lower limb. On Palpation Heaving LV impulse is noted, which is displaced laterally and inferiorly Diastolic and Systolic Thrills were noticed at the left lower sternal border and suprasternal notch, respectively. On Auscultation Heart Sounds A2 is absent In the Bicuspid aortic valve, systolic ejection sound is present Sometimes, A4 is also heard Murmurs A Decrescendo diastolic murmur, best heard when sitting up and leaning forward, is an early diastolic murmur that becomes holo-diastolic as the condition progresses to a severe stage. Musical diastolic murmur is aortic cusp fluttering in the regurgitant flow. Mid-diastolic murmur Austin Flint murmur is a soft, low-pitched, mid- to end-diastolic murmur caused by mitral valve displacement due to AR. Ejection systolic murmur is commonly heard in AR along with AS . Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 1988 heart.bmj.com/content/82/3/262 www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK557428/

questions.question: A 72-year-old male with a two-year history of severe aortic regurgitation presents with complaints of worsening dyspnea, angina and orthopnea. Physical examination reveals a loud diastolic murmur at the left sternal border and a widened pulse pressure. An echocardiogram indicates significant left ventricular dilation. What is the likely estimated regurgitant volume in this condition?
questions.explanation: An echocardiogram is utilised to detect changes and classify the condition as severe or progressive aortic regurgitation. Echocardiogram Findings for Aortic Regurgitation Severe Aortic regurgitation Progressive Aortic regurgitation Regurgitant Volume is > 60 ml/beat Regurgitant fraction is ≥ 50% Holodiastolic aortic flow reversal - blood flows backwards into the left ventricle throughout the diastolic phase. Diastolic flow reversal in the descending aorta. Ejection Fraction is 55 - 60 % Left ventricle end-systolic dimension (LVESD) is >50 mm Left ventricle end-diastolic dimension (LVEDD) is > 65 mm Acute Aortic Regurgitation Chronic Aortic Regurgitation It is a sudden onset of significant backflow from the aorta into the left ventricle, causing LV dilatation. This leads to pulmonary oedema, which can progress to acute heart failure. The presence of a water-hammer pulse/Corrigan’s pulse is a strong pulse that rises quickly and then drops off suddenly. Quincke's pulse (Capillary pulsations) The Frank-Starling law explains that blood flowing back into the left ventricle increases its contractions due to stretching of the ventricle walls. Reduced Cardiac output at rest. Both Preload and Afterload are increased ( Laplace law) LVH is common. High myocardial oxygen demand can lead to Myocardial ischemia. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 1987, 1988, 1989

questions.question: A 32-year-old female presents with intermittent palpitations, chest discomfort, and fatigue. A mid-systolic click and late systolic murmur are heard at the apex. Echocardiography shows mitral valve leaflets billowing into the left atrium during systole. Which of the following best explains the pathophysiology of this condition?

options.A: Inflammation of the mitral valve due to rheumatic fever
options.B: Fibrotic changes affecting the mitral valves
options.C: Rupture of the tendinae of the mitral valve
options.D: Myxomatous degeneration of mitral valve apparatus.

questions.explanation: the left atrium during systole, thus causing Mitral valve prolapse. MITRAL VALVE PROLAPSE Aetiology Most cases are idiopathic Myxomatous degeneration of the mitral valve apparatus (Reduced type III collagen production) Marfan syndrome (Fibrillin-1 protein defect) Ehler Danlos syndrome Osteogenesis imperfecta Straight back syndrome ( reduced thoracic kyphosis ) compresses the heart between the sternum and vertebrae, altering its position and increasing the likelihood of mitral valve prolapse (MVP). Pathophysiology mitral valve prolapse" data-author="" data-hash="8847" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" height="230" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/zNqtoziid3ggvNttuHvn1744309432.png" width="462" /> Clinical features Incidence More in females: 15-30 years Males: 50 years Severity: More severe in men than women Symptoms: Initially asymptomatic Palpitation and syncope due to premature ventricular contraction. Atypical features Substernal pain without exertion. Transient ischemic attack. Risk of endocarditis and Sudden cardiac death. If Mitral regurgitation (MR) occurs, it can lead to increased pressure in the lungs, causing frank pulmonary oedema. Auscultation findings of Mitral valve prolapse Mid or late non-ejection systolic click High-pitched mid-late systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur best heard at the apex. Change in auscultation findings with change in cavity size Condition Valsalva or Sudden Standing Squatting, Leg Raising, Standing to Supine, Isometric Exercises Preload and Afterload ↓ ↑ Cavity size ↓ ↑ Chordae tendineae stretching ↓ ↑ Timing of click The click occurs earlier, closer to S1 The click occurs later, away from S1 Murmur duration ↑ ↓ Inflammation of the mitral valve due to rheumatic fever (Option A) occurs in Rheumatic heart disease, which can result in fibrotic changes in the mitral valve (Option B), leading to mitral stenosis, which produces a low-pitched diastolic rumble. Rupture of the tendinae of the mitral valve (Option C) leads to acute severe mitral regurgitation, which can be a complication of mitral valve prolapse but is not the cause. Reference: Harrison’s Principle of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page 2000

questions.question: A 65-year-old woman reports experiencing mild chest pain and shortness of breath on exertion. Upon examination, a prominent ejection-type systolic murmur is noted, best heard at the right second intercostal space and radiating to the carotids. An Echocardiogram shows an aortic valve area of 0.9 cm², and ECG reveals Left ventricular hypertrophy. Which stage of aortic stenosis is suspected, and what is the ideal management? (TAVR: Transcatheter Aortic Valve Replacement)
questions.explanation: and is managed by Transcatheter Aortic Valve Replacement (TAVR). Stage Aortic Valve area Explanation Stage A Normal Patient with normal aortic valve functioning and presence of risk factors like: Old age Congenital valvular disease History of rheumatic fever History of endocarditis Genetic Polymorphisms HTN, DM, CKD, Smoking & High LDL. Stage B 1.5 - 2 cm² (Mild) It involves asymptomatic patients with mild to moderate stenosis. 1 - 1.5 cm² (Moderate) Stage C < 1 cm² Asymptomatic severe aortic stenosis Stage D < 1 cm² Symptomatic severe aortic stenosis Patients with aortic stenosis are typically managed medically unless they are symptomatic, with a few exceptions. Stage/Condition Management Asymptomatic with HTN or CAD Start ACE inhibitors or beta-blockers. Stage B Consider TAVR if LVEF < 60% (based on three readings). Regular monitoring with Doppler echocardiogram every 1-2 years to evaluate progression. Stage C Avoid strenuous exercise, hypovolemia, and dehydration to maintain adequate cardiac output. Indications for TAVR : LVEF < 50%. Ejection velocity > 5 m/sec. Transvalvular gradient (LV-AO) > 60 mmHg. Statins should be started to prevent the progression of atherosclerosis. Stage D TAVR is indicated. For pediatric patients with congenital aortic stenosis, aortic balloon valvuloplasty is the preferred treatment. Patients in Stage B and Stage C are monitored regularly with Doppler echocardiograms every 1 to 2 years to assess disease progression.

questions.question: A 72-year-old patient presents with angina and shortness of breath on exertion. Physical examination reveals a slow-rising carotid pulse and a systolic ejection murmur. An echocardiogram shows thickened and calcified aortic valve leaflets with reduced opening. Which of the following findings is most likely to be observed on the ECG in this patient?
questions.explanation: Aortic stenosis (AS). In this condition, the heart works harder to pump blood through the narrowed valve, leading to left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH), which is frequently observed on ECG due to the increased workload. Physical Findings: Heart Rate Generally regular until late stages. Atrial fibrillation (AF) may indicate associated mitral valve disease Blood Pressure It is commonly elevated in older adults with aortic stenosis (AS). In late stages, stroke volume declines, leading to potential systolic pressure drop and narrowed pulse pressure. Carotid Pulse Characterized by a slow rise and delayed peak (pulsus parvus et tardus/Anacrotic pulse) A thrill or anacrotic “shudder” may be felt over the carotid arteries, often more prominent on the left JVP Accentuated “a” wave due to reduced right ventricular (RV) cavity distensibility from the hypertrophied interventricular septum. LV Impulse Lateral displacement in advanced stages. A double apical impulse and palpable S4 may be noted, especially in the left lateral recumbent position. Auscultation findings: An early systolic ejection sound may be heard in younger patients with congenital bicuspid aortic valves, typically disappearing as the valve calcifies. Severe AS may cause aortic valve closure to coincide with pulmonic valve closure, leading to paradoxical splitting of S2 (Initial stages - Single S2) S4 sound at the apex indicates LV hypertrophy S3 appears in advanced stages when LV function declines. Murmur: (Crescendo-Decrescendo Murmur) Ejection (mid) systolic murmur begins shortly after S1, increases in intensity, and ends before aortic valve closure. It is characterized as low-pitched and rough, typically loudest at the second right intercostal space. It can radiate to the carotid arteries and may be mistaken for mitral regurgitation due to the Gallavardin effect , where high-frequency components are perceived over the apex. Electrocardiography (ECG): LV hypertrophy is common in severe AS. Advanced cases may show ST-segment depression and T-wave inversion (LV strain), but these findings do not always correlate with hemodynamic severity. Echocardiography: It reveals thickened, calcified valve leaflets, reduced systolic opening, and LV hypertrophy. Congenital bicuspid valves show eccentric closure. Doppler measurements estimate valve gradient and area; Severe AS is defined by a valve area <1 cm² Right atrial enlargement (Option B) is not typical in isolated aortic stenosis but may occur in other conditions, such as tricuspid valve disease. ST-segment elevation (Option C) indicates acute myocardial infarction , which is not the primary finding in aortic stenosis. Atrial fibrillation (Option D) can occur in aortic stenosis but is uncommon as an initial finding and is more often associated with mitral valve involvement or significant atrial dilation can occur, but it is not a common initial finding in AS and is primarily associated with mitral valve involvement.

questions.question: A 65-year-old patient presents to the clinic with increasing fatigue and shortness of breath on exertion. O/E a harsh, systolic crescendo-decrescendo ejection murmur is noted at the right second intercostal space. Which of the following symptoms is not part of the classic triad associated with this condition?
questions.explanation: systolic crescendo-decrescendo ejection murmur typically heard at the right second intercostal space. Orthopnea typically indicates HF/conditions related to fluid overload, but it is not one of the hallmark symptoms of aortic stenosis. Aortic Stenosis: Symptom onset: AS is clinically significant when the aortic valve orifice narrows to ~1 cm². Severe AS can remain asymptomatic for years due to LV compensation. Symptom progression: Often develops in the sixth to eighth decades; patients with bicuspid aortic valves may experience symptoms 10-20 years earlier. Clinical Manifestations of Aortic Stenosis: The classic triad of symptoms: Exertional dyspnea (Option A ruled out) : Shortness of breath during physical activity due to elevated pulmonary capillary pressure from impaired left ventricular function and reduced cardiac output. Angina pectoris (Option B ruled out) : Chest pain occurs due to myocardial ischemia in aortic stenosis, resulting from increased oxygen demand and decreased supply. Syncope (Option C ruled out) : Loss of consciousness due to reduced cerebral perfusion, often occurring during exertion Early symptoms : Fatigue and reduced exercise tolerance. Advanced stages: Orthopnea (Option D) Paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea Pulmonary edema. Late Findings: RV failure Systemic venous hypertension Hepatomegaly Atrial fibrillation Tricuspid regurgitation Interactions with Other Conditions: Mitral stenosis can mask AS symptoms by lowering cardiac output, while aortic regurgitation may increase the transaortic pressure gradient due to higher flow rates. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 1980,1981

questions.question: A 72-year-old woman presents with fatigue and progressive shortness of breath, particularly when climbing stairs. During the physical examination, a harsh, systolic ejection murmur is heard at the right second intercostal space, radiating to the carotids. Which of the following factors is least likely to be associated with the development of the condition?
questions.explanation: radiating to the carotids suggests Aortic Stenosis . While mediastinal irradiation, mutation in NOTCH1, and prior rheumatic inflammation are all factors associated with aortic valve dysfunction. Systemic lupus erythematosus is less directly linked to the development of Aortic Stenosis. Etiology of Aortic stenosis (AS): Degenerative Calcification The primary cause of aortic stenosis (AS) in adults, often due to: Congenital Bicuspid Aortic Valve (BAV) : Approximately 53% of cases. Trileaflet Valve Deterioration Previous Rheumatic Fever (Option C ruled out) : Inflammation can lead to scarring and calcification. Rheumatic Heart Disease It causes commissural fusion, resembling BAV, and leads to valve narrowing. Mediastinal Radiation (Option A ruled out) Cause late scarring and calcification of the aortic leaflets. Shone Complex Components include Aortic stenosis , Coarctation of aorta, Parachute mitral valve, supravalvular mitral membrane Genetic polymorphisms Vitamin D receptor Estrogen receptor (notably in postmenopausal women) Interleukin 10 Apolipoprotein E4 Traditional risk factors Hypertension, High LDL, Smoking, DM, CKD Bicuspid Aortic Valve Disease Most common congenital heart valve defect, with a male predominance (2–4:1) . Inheritance : Autosomal dominant with incomplete penetrance Genetic Factors : Mutations in NOTCH1 (Option B ruled out) , GATA5 , and GATA4 have been noted

questions.question: A 65-year-old male presents with exertional dyspnea and a prominent heart murmur. Upon auscultation, the murmur is best heard at the right second intercostal space and radiates to the carotids. Interestingly, the murmur also becomes higher-pitched when heard at the apex. What is the most likely diagnosis associated with this auscultatory finding?
questions.explanation: stenosis. Gallavardin Effect: It refers to the phenomenon where a murmur of aortic stenosis (AS) becomes higher-pitched and more acoustically pure when auscultated at the apex of the heart despite originating from the aortic region. The murmur is transmitted along the carotid arteries, which is a classic sign of AS When the murmur is auscultated at the apex, it may appear higher-pitched and can sometimes be confused with the systolic murmur of mitral regurgitation. Clinical Implication: The Gallavardin effect is important for differentiating between AS and other conditions like mitral regurgitation, as the change in pitch can lead to diagnostic confusion. Mitral regurgitation (Option A) typically presents with a holosystolic murmur best heard at the apex radiating to the axilla, not the carotids. It is unrelated to the right second intercostal space. Tricuspid regurgitation (Option C) produces a holosystolic murmur at the lower left sternal border that increases with inspiration and does not typically radiate to the carotids. Pulmonary stenosis (Option D) causes a systolic murmur best heard at the left upper sternal border, often radiating to the left shoulder or back. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 279,1981

questions.question: A 60-year-old female patient presents with exertional dyspnea and a history of rheumatic fever. An echocardiogram shows isolated mitral stenosis with a calcified valve. Which of the following is the most appropriate management strategy for her condition?
questions.explanation: calcified valve, particularly when heavy calcification makes the valve unsuitable for balloon valvuloplasty. Management of Mitral Stenosis: Medical Management: Patients with mild symptoms may be managed medically. Penicillin Prophylaxis : Essential for preventing rheumatic fever in risk patients. Symptomatic Relief : Sodium restriction, diuretics, beta-blockers (Option D ruled out), and Calcium channel blockers help manage symptoms and control heart rate in atrial fibrillation (AF). Anticoagulation : Warfarin for patients with AF, history of thromboembolism, or left atrial thrombus; INR target 2–3. (Option A ruled out) Cardioversion : For recent-onset AF, ensure anticoagulation for at least three weeks. Infective Endocarditis Prophylaxis : Routine antibiotic prophylaxis is no longer recommended. Interventional: Considered if patients remain symptomatic despite medical management or if pulmonary hypertension develops/Severe MS (<1.5 cm²) Balloon valvuloplasty Mitral valvotomy/Mitral valve replacement Procedure Indications / Requirements Mitral Balloon Valvuloplasty (PMBC) (Option B ruled out) Significant symptoms present Isolated mitral stenosis (no or trivial mitral regurgitation) Mobile, non-calcified valve/sub valve apparatus on echocardiogram Left atrium free of thrombus Surgical Commissurotomy Required if PMBC fails Involves opening valve commissures and addressing subvalvular structures Mitral Valve Replacement (Option C) Substantial mitral regurgitation Rigid and calcified valve Presence of thrombus formation Mitral Balloon Valvuloplasty/Percutaneous Mitral Balloon Commissurotomy:

questions.question: A 48-year-old female presents with worsening exertional dyspnea and fatigue. She has a history of rheumatic fever during her childhood. O/E, you note a diastolic murmur at the cardiac apex, along with a pronounced opening snap. Which of the following findings is least likely to be present?
questions.explanation: of a diastolic murmur with an opening snap strongly suggests Mitral stenosis & the primary issue is obstruction, leading to left atrial enlargement and a reduced mitral valve area. Mitral regurgitation is less likely unless there is additional valve pathology. Mitral Stenosis (MS): Aetiology: Primary Cause : Rheumatic fever is the leading cause of mitral stenosis, accounting for about 40% of cases in patients with a history of rheumatic heart disease. Congenital abnormalities (e.g., parachute valve, cor triatriatum) Mitral annular calcification with involvement of leaflets Autoimmune diseases (e.g., systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis) Left atrial myxoma Infective endocarditis with large vegetation Pathology : Chronic inflammation leads to thickening of the valve leaflets, fibrous tissue formation, calcific deposits, and fusion of the mitral commissures and chordae tendinae. This process results in a narrowed, funnel-shaped valve. (Fish-mouth Appearance) Normal mitral valve area : 4–6 cm²; significant obstruction if <2 cm². (Option B ruled out) Hemodynamics : In severe MS (<1.5 cm²), a left atrial (LA) pressure of ~25 mmHg is needed to maintain normal cardiac output (CO). Effects of Heart Rate : Increased heart rate diminishes diastolic filling time, raising the LA pressure and transvalvular gradient Symptoms : Exertional dyspnea, cough, and progressive limitation of daily activities. Orthopnea and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea can develop as MS worsens. Atrial fibrillation (AF) often accelerates symptom progression. Complications: Pulmonary Hypertension (Leading to RVH & RHF) (Option C ruled out) Atrial Fibrillation (Due to Left atrial enlargement) Thrombus Formation: Stasis of blood in the enlarged left atrium, increases the risk of thrombus formation, especially in patients with atrial fibrillation. Hemoptysis (Elevated pulmonary venous pressure - rupture of small veins) Infective Endocarditis Pulmonary Infections Findings: Inspection : Malar flush, jugular venous distension, and right ventricular (RV) enlargement. Auscultation : A loud S1, an opening snap (OS) after S2, and a low-pitched, rumbling mid-diastolic murmur with presystolic accentuation- heard best at the apex. Characteristics of a murmur in severe MS : Decreased interval between A2 & OS. Wide splitting of S2. Palpable systolic thrill. The duration of the murmur increases. murmur in severe MS" data-author="" data-hash="8856" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" height="532" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/Ch2RCevxGFGKiw3DvKhT1744310319.png" width="532" /> Investigations: ECG : Often shows LA enlargement (Option A ruled out) , right axis deviation, and RV hypertrophy. Echocardiogram : Measures mitral inflow velocity and transvalvular gradients and evaluates for associated mitral regurgitation (MR) or other valvular lesions. Chest X-ray : Shows LA enlargement, pulmonary vein dilation, and Kerley B lines indicating pulmonary congestion.

questions.question: A 62-year-old female with a history of rheumatic heart disease comes to the OPD for a regular follow-up. Echocardiography confirmed the presence of severe mitral regurgitation (MR). When considering her treatment options, which of the following interventions should not be included in her management plan? ≥ 2

options.A: Use of Apixaban if her CHA2DS2-VASc score
options.C: Mitral valve repair if ejection fraction falls less than 60%

questions.explanation: ≥ 2 I DS I -VASc score is a clinical prediction tool used to estimate the risk of stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation (AF), and if a patient has a CHA2DS2-VASc score ≥ 2, it means that he is at a high risk of stroke and anticoagulation is recommended. In patients with RHD, especially those with mitral valve disease, Vitamin K antagonists (VKAs) like warfarin are the preferred anticoagulants for preventing thromboembolic events, particularly if atrial fibrillation is present. Non-vitamin K oral anticoagulants (NOACs) like apixaban are generally not recommended for patients with rheumatic mitral valve disease, as these agents have not been well studied or proven to be safe and effective in this population. Management of Mitral Regurgitation Investigations ECG Atrial fibrillation may be present in cases of chronic MR P-mitrale > 120 seconds (enlarged left atrium) Echocardiogram Regurgitant flow of blood from the left ventricle to the left atrium Chest X-ray Double atrial shadow (left atrium enlarged) Walking man sign ( ↑ carinal angle) Signs of pulmonary oedema: Pulmonary congestion and Kerley B lines. Left ventricular dilatation due to volume overload (MS, there is compensatory hypertrophy) Treatment Acute MR leading to decompensated heart failure can be treated with: Loop diuretics Sodium nitroprusside Mechanical support till surgical repair Chronic MR For secondary MR, aggressive guideline-directed therapy (GDMT) can be done using. Beta-blockers (Atenolol and Metoprolol) ACE inhibitors (Lisinopril and Captopril) Angiotensin receptor blockers (Telmisartan and Losartan) Cardiac resynchronization therapy for arrhythmias (Option B ruled out) Warfarin or NOAC if atrial fibrillation occurs NOAC should be avoided in the presence of rheumatic heart disease and mechanical prosthetic valves (Option A) Warfarin is preferred in RHD with valvular atrial fibrillation (Option D ruled out) Surgical repair: Mitral valve repair > replacement Transcatheter mitral valve repair (Mitra clip) Surgical repair in asymptomatic patients must be done when EF<60% or LV ESD >= 40mm. (Option C ruled out)

questions.question: A 65-year-old female presents to the clinic with complaints of fatigue, shortness of breath on exertion, and palpitations. On physical examination, a systolic thrill is palpable at the cardiac apex. Echocardiography showed severe backflow of blood from the left ventricle to the left atrium during ventricular systole. What kind of murmur is most likely to be heard during cardiac auscultation of this patient?

options.B: An opening snap followed by a diastolic murmur
options.C: Holosystolic murmur, best heard at the apex
options.D: Crescendo decrescendo systolic murmur best heard at the base

questions.explanation: cardiac auscultation, a holosystolic murmur will most likely be heard at the cardiac apex. MITRAL REGURGITATION Clinical examination BP may be normal or ↓ ; Narrow pulse pressure. Palpable thrill at the cardiac apex. Hyperdynamic and laterally displaced apex beat. Normal or ↑ JVP. Auscultation findings Soft or absent S1. Wide variable splitting of S2: P2 is variable, and A2 appears early as less blood flows through the aortic valve; thus, the S2 split is wide. S4 may be heard in acute severe MR. Murmur Holosystolic murmur in chronic MR . (High-pitched blowing murmur, radiating towards axilla) A decrescendo early systolic murmur in acute severe MR. Continuous murmurs (Option A) occur during both systole and diastole, which is not characteristic of mitral regurgitation. They are typically associated with conditions that involve persistent blood flow between high- and low-pressure areas, such as in patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), where there is a constant flow of blood between the aorta and pulmonary artery. An opening snap followed by a diastolic murmur (Option B) is heard in mitral stenosis . It occurs due to the narrowed mitral valve opening during diastole, resulting in an opening snap followed by a low-pitched diastolic rumble. Crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur (Option C) is typical of aortic stenosis . It is heard best at the base of the heart and radiates to the carotids. This murmur reflects the turbulent flow of blood through the narrowing of the aortic valve. Reference: Harrison’s Principle of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page 284, 1996,1981

questions.question: A 72-year-old male with mitral valve prolapse, chronic atrial fibrillation (CHA2DS2-VASc score of 5), severe mitral regurgitation, and an ejection fraction of 35% presents with occasional palpitations and breathlessness. He also has a history of infective endocarditis. Which of the following statements regarding his management is not true?

options.B: Beta-blockers should be initiated for his palpitations
options.C: Mitral valve repair is preferred over mitral valve replacement

questions.explanation: reduce the risk of cerebrovascular accident . CHA2DS2-VASc: The CHA2DS2-VASc score is a clinical tool used to estimate the risk of stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation (AF) and to guide anticoagulation therapy. C ongestive heart failure (1 point) H ypertension (1 point) A ge ≥ 75 years (2 points) D iabetes mellitus (1 point) S troke/TIA/TE history (2 points) V ascular disease (1 point) A ge 65-74 years (1 point) S ex category (female sex, 1 point) Scoring: 0 points : Low risk (consider no anticoagulation) 1 point : Moderate risk (consider anticoagulation, especially if female) 2 or more points : High risk (anticoagulation recommended) Investigations ECG Biphasic or inverted T waves in lead II, III and aVF Occasional Supraventricular tachycardia and Premature Ventricular Contraction may be seen Transthoracic echocardiography (parasternal long axis view) Bulge > 2mm above mitral annulus (belly of mitral valve leaflet) Transesophageal echocardiography Indicated when more accurate anatomic information is required. Done during surgery for intraoperative guidance during valvular repair. Management: Palpitations: Beta Blockers (Option B ruled out) Atrial fibrillation/prevention of stroke (Option A) Anticoagulants should be initiated if the CHA2DS2-VASc score is more than or equal to 2. Transient ischemic attack (mild): Low-dose aspirin Endocarditis prophylaxis (Option D ruled out): Antibiotics are indicated if a history of endocarditis is present. Surgical repair (Option C ruled out): Transcatheter valvular repair is preferred over replacement (Repair preserves the native valve, improves outcomes, and decreases postoperative complications)
